distribution.text: Copyright Â© Red Hat, Inc. All rights reserved.

notes.text:
An update for kernel is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.7 Extended Update Support.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
The kernel packages contain the Linux kernel, the core of any Linux operating system.

Security Fix(es):

* kernel: locking issue in drivers/tty/tty_jobctrl.c can lead to an use-after-free (CVE-2020-29661)

* kernel: performance counters race condition use-after-free (CVE-2020-14351)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.

Bug Fix(es):

* Openstack network node reports unregister_netdevice: waiting for qr-3cec0c92-9a to become free. Usage count = 1 (BZ#1908539)
notes.title: Details

notes.title: Terms of Use

publisher.issuing_authority: Red Hat Product Security is responsible for vulnerability handling across all Red Hat products and services.
publisher.name: Red Hat Product Security

document.title: Red Hat Security Advisory: kernel security and bug fix update

notes.text: A flaw was found in the Linux kernel. A use-after-free memory flaw was found in the perf subsystem allowing a local attacker with permission to monitor perf events to corrupt memory and possibly escalate privileges.  The highest threat from this vulnerability is to data confidentiality and integrity as well as system availability.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: performance counters race condition use-after-free
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7.2 and later kernels default to a safe /proc/sys/kernel/perf_event_paranoid setting; local administrators may have reason to change the setting to allow non privileged users to monitor performance statistics.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.

While there is no way to disable the perf subsystem on Linux systems, reducing or removing users access to the perf events can effectively mitigate this flaw. Upstream kernel documentation has been written regarding this mechanism: https://www.kernel.org/doc/html/latest/admin-guide/perf-security.html.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: performance counters race condition use-after-free

notes.text: A locking vulnerability was found in the tty subsystem of the Linux kernel in drivers/tty/tty_jobctrl.c. This flaw allows a local attacker to possibly corrupt memory or escalate privileges. The highest threat from this vulnerability is to confidentiality, integrity, as well as system availability.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: locking issue in drivers/tty/tty_jobctrl.c can lead to an use-after-free
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.
Red Hat has investigated whether a possible mitigation exists for this issue, and has not been able to identify a practical example. Please update as soon as possible.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: locking issue in drivers/tty/tty_jobctrl.c can lead to an use-after-free
